description.text: This is a ball-chain pulley for 3.5mm ball chain, intended for use as part of a Polargraph: http://www.polargraph.co.uk/ Regular metal ball-chain was easier to locate versus the type that Sandy had used on his Polargraph. I use a slightly modified version of Ed's stepper motor mounts as well: http://softsolder.com/2011/08/23/nema-17-stepper-motor-mount/ The ball-chain I'm using came from here: http://www.kitkraft.biz/product.php?productid=8353&cat=&page=2 Update: The gondola I printed for mine is here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:12557 - and it works!
Pulley is sized for a 5mm shaft, and has a 3mm bolt / nut setup for tensioning on the shaft.   If this doesn't match your stepper, edit the .scad file and change it up.

A multiple clothes hanger organizer that allows you to cram even more items of clothing into limited hanging space.
This, like so many things, was created to make my wife happy. Unfortunately she is restricted to a mere three closets (love you honey ;) ) and as such, does not have enough hanging space to store all of her clothes that can't be kept in drawers for reasons beyond my understanding.
This is not a completely original concept, I saw something similar on a late night infomercial at some point maybe a decade ago and this design came to mind. Please feel free to use and modify as you see fit.
It can hold a decent amount of weight printed in PLA, I was able to hang a leather jacket and two heavy sweaters from one without issue or bending. I'm sure ABS or Nylon would be able to hold even heavier items.

Printer:

Reprap Prusa i2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Infill:

30%

Notes: I don't recommend anything lower than 20% infill unless you are only hanging very lightweight items. I had no problems at all with 30%.

title: Parametric E3D clone / Jhead / Hot end mount with proximity sensor

description.text:
Designed for an E3D hot end clone, with a proximity sensor. There's also plenty of room between the hotend and prox. sensor for almost any fan you want to clip onto the hot end. The following (among other things) are easily changed in the SCAD file:
Hot end heatsink diameter (if you have a genuine E3D)
Hot end height
Prox. sensor diameter, (if you have a 18mm prox. sensor)
Distance between the hot end & prox. sensor (if you need more room for a fan)
Mounting hole width (currently set the same as a 40mm fan / Nema17 stepper) Designed to be printed in the same orientation it loads into your slicer. Mine printed fine without support and without raft. Thanks to Gargouille for the OpenSCAD code I used for holding the E3D collar, It works, but note that it's an intentionally a TIGHT fit. To make it a little less tight fit change this line in the SCAD file:
module JHead(diameters = [12, 16, 25], dimensions = [3.7, 9.3, 12.3, 18.3, 50.1]) {
try changing the 9.3 dimension to 9.1 or less. Note that some proximity sensors require 12v to power them and need a voltage divider circuit on the signal wire to reduce it down to 5v for the RAMPS board. The Hot end retainer is held in place with 20mm long m3 nuts. Updated: Jan 16, 2016 to change the holes for the nuts, reduce the distance between the hot end and the sensor, and reduce overall length. Now uses 16mm long M3 nuts.

Note that some proximity sensors require 12v to power them and need a voltage divider circuit on the signal wire to reduce it down to 5v for the RAMPS board.
The Hot end retainer is held in place with 20mm long m3 nuts.

title: TARDIS Deluxe Kit
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
TARDIS files have been updated as of 4-11-16. Includes new, simplified lighting parts and side panels to accommodate them. The new panels will still work with the old-style LED parts. Be sure to download and read the new TARDIS_Print_Guide.PDF Lighting kits and labels are available on my Etsy store:
https://charlesworthdynamics.etsy.com Charlesworth Dynamics is pleased to offer the TARDIS Deluxe Kit. I have yet to get a satisfactory print out of a TARDIS which prints standing up, so I designed this to print flat. It turns out better, faster and offers some nice customization options. This is based directly off BBC blueprints from around Eccleston or early Tennant. Everything is designed to slot or snap together so glue isn't necessary except for the lamp top to lamp shade since it's so tiny. The top comes off so the TARDIS can be used as a pencil holder, container, etc. Use the solid base in this case.

Make sure to download and read the 'TARDIS_Print_Guide.PDF'.
If you have a PTouch label maker that interfaces with a computer, use the LBX files for labels, otherwise there are JPGs.

comments.text:
Forever a Dr Who fan, I just had to make one of these! I ordered the lighting kit from Charlesworth-dynamics.com and started printing parts. The parts print well but be careful when separating the raft around Tardis's windows, the window frames are delicate.
Assembly is easy and the parts fit each other nice but you may need to do a little extra cleaning and fitting.
The lighting is a challenge and if you don't do much soldering this will be a real test of your patience. I was able to get the LED's all wired up on the first try and the Tardis looks amazing!

7 Teachings of the Anishinaabe / Ojibwe people.
Modeled after http://ojibweresources.weebly.com/ojibwe-teachings--the-7-grandfathers.html in a geometric Medicine Wheel. White - North, Yellow - South, Black - East and Red - West. author: Auram

description.text:
I printed this with PLA unsupported, although it needs cooling on the very last layers for how quick and close together they are.  ABS should work too.  The files include high, medium, and low resolution models.  I printed from the high resolution one, but the lower resolutions may work just fine and should be easier for most software to work with.
Usage: Start with one end of your coil wire sticking down through the center, and bend over a short bit that comes out.  Then at the top of the cone spiral, begin winding the wire on to the spiral groove track while pulling to keep tension, and using a free finger or two (from the hand holding the base of this tool) to help hold down the wire wraps that have been made so far.  I usually wrap until it's halfway down the cone, which gives me a coil with 1ohm resistance.  
When you're done wrapping, unbend the wire hook and slide everything up off the tool.  Then you'll need to pull the middle wire to bend this cone-shaped spring inside-out, until when you release it comes back to a flat disc of coil instead of cone-shaped.  Or maybe you want cone-shaped, that's an option too.  Then bend your middle and edge wires to suitably feed into your posts, and usually there's just enough room to feed a screwdriver in through the center hole for its post, while the outer post is easy enough.
For a wick, one option is to cut a long skinny piece of cotton, and feed it into the spiral and pull it around with tweezers, until your wick is all throughout the coil.  Juice it to lay down, and you're done.  Make sure when putting the housing back on, that it doesn't hit the coil or wick (this ends up much taller than building small coils down on the sides like normal).  But when working properly, a person can see down through the mouthpiece and be looking right on top of a nice flat evenly-heating burner surface, suitable for a variety of juices, waxes, juices with herbs, or even dry herbs perhaps.
Just thought this was something I hadn't really seen, and bending one nicely sure benefited from having a 3D-printed wrapping tool like this.  Enjoy.

title: Distagon f/4 40 mm C lens hood

description.text:
I recently purchased a Hasselblad 40mm C f/4. I love medium format cameras and lenses. The are sharp, work very well, and are built to last, this lens is no exception.It's a beast weighing in at 1.375kg ~3lbs. I've been scared to shoot it because I didn't have a filter to mount on it. Older series Hasselblad lenses (and some Rolleis) take bayonet style filters and lens hoods. They work great but are hard to come by, and expensive if you do find them. My idea was to design a lens hood that I could print and mount to the camera. It takes a b104 filter, and hood. Which means bayonet 104mm diameter! I did some research and found there was a rubber lens hood that was sold to fit this camera, but I haven't been able to find one for sale, or borrow for reference. The CAD I have posted is all from looking at lots of pictures, and taking measurements from the lens, and a b60 lens hood I have from another lens. The flickr link below is a nice image the same lens as mine...
http://flic.kr/p/cifyDh

Just print the lens hood. Attach to your camera and enjoy! Update 8.27.2013
  • Printed version in ABS very sturdy pics to come
  • Increased bayonet diameter fit was too snug
  • Final version!
    • Update 8.1.2013
  • Thickened the bayonet ring
  • Tweaked Baynote diameter
  • Still tuning the maxium rotation
    • Update 8.1.2013
  • Tweek to the hood diameter it was still a little too big
  • Thickened the material around bayonet mount for durability
    • Update 7.30.2013
  • Added a taper to the lens hood to make it a little stronger, and more representative of the original rubber version
  • Changed the bayonet mount to be a friction/interference fit instead using faux detents
  • Fixed hood diameter. Previous version too big.
    • Disclaimer I have not printed this on a RepRap or Makerbot yet. I have access to a Stratsys Vantage that uses a water soluable support material.

A Tiny Advent Wreath done in OpenSCAD
This project started out as an experiment with some code for making "chained hulls". First I generated the twisted torus (see the strand() module around line 50). The idea is to make a series of disks that are offset slightly around the main ring perimeter and then use the hull() function fills the gaps . 
When I got it working I decided it would make a nice looking advent wreath ornament for my Christmas tree. I actually had a much more ambitious project in mind using programmable LEDs to get purple and pink candles, during advent and then change to white.  That didn't happen because of a catastrophic disk failure of my dual boot system following a windows update. Just now recovering my Linux /user area.
So, sorry this is a bit late for the Christmas season. Hey, we keep the tree up till Epiphany so have at it! The .stl file is sized for birthday cake candles. Warning: please don't light them, they are strictly decorative and will only last long enough for a couple verses of "Happy Birthday to You". I would be very sad if you burned your house down. Meanwhile I'll get started on the LED version, right after I setup a cron job for automated backups...
Thanks for looking!
Bob M

This tool storage system utilizes the vacant sides of the printer. As shown, i have my jewelers tool set on the system. I have used a dovetail railing system at the top to join the pieces together. author: Fitzroy

description.text:
You will need a couple of 3 x 20 mm adjustment screws to complete.  I drilled a mounting hole in my existing Z endstop to allow it to be mounted on the stepper motor plate.  I had to file a square area for the limit switch since it had to go on the other side.
I suggest using PLA as it is harder and more stable than ABS.
For the arrow component, make sure you start the threads so the screw goes in straight.  I did this while still on the bed.  Then when you thread it onto the adjustment screw, allow the screw to protrude about a quarter inch past the disc so that only the screw engages the limit switch.
If you insert an M600 command at layer height Z=2.2, you can change filament colors to have a contrasting color for the arrow.
EDIT 12/19/2017: added version 3 which uses a 3mm nut pressed in with a pair of pliers for a tight fit and two 20mm length 3mm fine thread screws for securing the bracket and one for the  adjuster screw.
My original version was starting to show some wear in the threads because I did not use a 3mm nut, so I reworked the STL file to include it.
I printed this at .2mm using Black and Yellow PLA.  I inserted an M600 command at layer height 2.2mm to pause the print and change filament.

author: gvogele

description.text: Kneel before Zo... I mean, hey look what you can do with experimental dual extruders on a MakerBot - grayscale vector art.  This is an attempt to show how by designing your model so that you vary the number of layers between two colors, you can do some simple color mixing.

For more info on how to make shapes in inkscape and extrude them in openscad, see: http://tonybuser.com/2d-to-3d You will need to use at least Skeinforge 40 to slice these models. Skeinforge 35 has a bug where shapes enclosed inside other shapes cause the shapes inside to have 0 infill. The models have an extra layer on top because of a bug in replicatorg where it doesn't print the top layer in a dual extrusion operation... luckily it will be easy to change by modifying the scad script.

This is a license plate delete with a boxer engine design in it. Designed to fit well on Subaru WRX's... At least 2008-2014s asother years have slightly different license plate patterns on the front bumper, the holes should line up but might not match the bumper as well. Anyways, its an "artistic" interpretation of a boxer or flat engine when viewed from the front. This is a simple version of the light up one I made in my video, which can be seen here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hrY0TnggGwU This version is designed to be a stand alone piece like the one I held up in the beginning of the video.

Notes: I would recommend ABS or another material that will hold up well against the elements. You will also need a large print volume printer. I had to print rotated 45 degrees (corner to corner) on the print bed to get it to fit. I have a Lulzbot Kittaz which has a pretty large build area.

A Simple Clip hook that uses friction to hold on to the back of the stairs in my apartment.  Its able to hold quite a bit of weight
This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/d8bg1GJ3L90 size is 50 x 50 x 5mm .

How is it made Good thing I have made with tinkercad, pretty easy to do even for a beginner is to make a tag. they are both halves one is a blank with a hole to repeat copy that and use it for second layer, just add words from text and the style once that done, join them together as one piece, My printer has one extrusion, I just let it print, and a cutter is needed, when the start of the letters is printed, cut the end close to the insert of extrusion before the motor, then add a different colour. Have to remember to push and hold the second filament for till the colour change.
Much quicker than to change by hand

title: Watercolor Palette Cups for Mint Tins

description.text:
Update 2016-04-10: Added a double wide, double high sponge cup and new default arrangement for the OpenSCAD file. This OpenSCAD program will generate some small cups that can be used to hold watercolor paints. I got the idea from this instructable:
http://www.instructables.com/id/Movable-Pallet-Altoid-Tin-Watercolor-Set/ The author shows "1/2-pans" for watercolors mounted in an Altoid Tin with magnets. Honestly, the commercial ones are probably much cheaper and easier to clean than these cups. But if you only need a few to hold your favorite colors, these might be a way to go. I also included code to create a "tool tray" with rounded corners and an extra long cup example. Either of these could be used to hold a sawed-off paintbrush for a tidy little paint set. If you'd like some other sizes, you can hack the basic_cup_size or xl_cup_size arrays. The 14mm height takes it to just below the hinge cutout. You could make them a little shorter if you'd like. The 19mm x 15.25mm footprint lets you put up to 16 color cups in a single tin with a nice snug fit. You could also make other sizes and if you stick to multiples of 19mm and 15.25mm they should still fit. Maybe a 38mm x 30.5mm cup to hold a sponge? You could also use these with thing 753052 (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:753052) by adjusting the size to something like 20.0 x 16 x 10.0 mm and optionally setting the rounding radius to 0 like this: use <MintyInserts.scad> import("altoids_tin_watercolor_palette.stl"); special_cup_size = [20.0, 16, 10.0]; color("White") translate([-12.5, -14, 3]) rounded_interior_cup(special_cup_size, rr=0); Thanks for looking!
Bob M

comments.text: I am the author of that Instructibles link on magnetic cups.  I am now downloading your STL to use on my own new 3D printer.  It is the great circle of life.  Thanks and cheers!
comments.author: thehaggard

comments.text: Thanks sir! I'm glad you enjoyed them.You might have to adjust the Z-scaling slightly if you put magnets on the back. They might be a little too tall depending how thick the magnet strips are. Maybe set the Z-scale at 90% while keeping X and Y at 100%. Your slicer software should be able do this.

title: Bulldozer Majorette 1/56e shovel mechanism repair kit

description.text:
This is a replacement kit for the entire shovel mechanism of the Majorette 1/56e Bulldozer. (the first pic is the dozer out of the box; found on the internet) It is designed to look like the original mechanism, so it is not optimized for 3D printing via FDM (lots of small cylindrical shape). Bill of material :

  • Printing

    • 2x Cylinder bracket
    • 2x Cylinder
    • 2x Cylinder rod
    • Crank
    • Lever 1
    • Lever 2
  • Other
    • 1x 2.5mm diameter rod, 25mm long
    • 1x 2mm diameter rod, 21mm long

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 2X

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm (may be better with less)

Infill:

10%

Notes: Since it was printed with 2 shells the infill value is not important Printed with 3rd fan

Some sanding and drilling may be needed.
Mounting instructions :
1- Glue the 2mm rod in the middle hole of lever 1 and 2. The pins on the levers should be outside (see picture)
2- Mount the 2.5mm rod and the cylinder bracket near the cabin (see picture)
3- Mount Cylindre on Cylinder rod
4- Mount Crank on the shovel (small side of the crank)
5- Mount levers in the middle of bulldozer arms (pins of levers in the holes)
6- Connect Cylinder rod on the levers (pins of rod in the levers' lower holes)
7- Glue Cylinder on cylinder brackets (carefull : do not glue the cylinder rod !!!)
8- Connect Crank on the levers (pins of Crank in the levers' upper holes)
9- Enjoy your rebuilt mechanism

author: mattsi

description.text: Dremel 4000 mount for Sherline 5400 CNC machine, based on http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:599893. Printed on a Stratasys Dimension Elite using solid fill ABS and sparse support, took about 41 hours. In order to mount to the column of the machine, part "Sherline5400_ColumnMount" must be machined, preferably out of aluminum for rigidity. The column adapter is from http://www.hteck.ca/lathe-mill/Dremel_headstock/dremel-headstock.html. We decided to create this part and not use the entire design from that site due to machining time -- we figured we'd rather let the printer take care of it than babysit the CNC.

The STC-1000 is a simple thermostat that can be bought on Amazon, eBay, AliExpress and so on. It's very handy for controlling heating and cooling, including fans, anything up to 10 amps.
This is a rough stand-in which you can use to design panels and enclosures around. I didn't include the panel retention tabs. Allow 3mm space around the body to fit those. The retention tabs can securely clip to panel thicknesses from less than 1mm to 16mm.
The needed hole cutout is 70mm wide, 29mm tall, leave at least 3mm around the cutout for the flange.
I've exported into several CAD file formats, use the one that imports the best.

description.text:
This is a mount I designed for the Folgertech 2020 Prusa i3  or any other Prusa i3 that uses similar X carrier and BLTouch Auto Level Sensor. 
The BLTouch sensor replaces servo endstop type auto bed leveler and the proximity sensors. It's basically an all in one Auto Bed Sensor and works great!
I wanted a slim profile for looks and functionality. The mount has mounting holes for the BLTouch and access hole for the adjustment grub screw on top of the BLTouch. Mount the BLTouch to the E3D mount first because the supplied 2mm screw and nut is harder to reach if the mount is mounted to the X-Carrier. Because of the large profile of the mount, it only requires two M3x25 machine screws. The mount is thick and stiff so there should not be any flex in the mount itself. You will want the lock nut inserted into the rear of the X-Carrier. An easy way is to screw the nut onto the screw backwards and then pressure fit it into the X-Carrier. Remove the screw and mount it from the front of the mount. I used M3x25mm machine screws for the clamp. It was too long but that's all I had in hand. 
The Folgertech kits come with wire holders thingie mabob.. I used that on the right side of the mount to hold all the wires together nice and neat. See Photo..
I printed with ABS because my printer is calibrated for ABS. I have not tried PLA, but it does not mean you can't use PLA. Print with the back of the mount on the built plate. The STL file should have it orientated as is. 
Please share if you printed... Thanks!
You can use the stock extruder it came with and print out a block I designed to adapt a bowden tube to it..

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

2020 Prusa i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

25

Notes: I printed at 25% infill and it is still stiff enough. You can play around with whatever infill percentage you would like. I would not go under 25% though.

title: Micro Quad 125mm 10G FPV | Beef's - VA1100 - FrSKY

description.text: This is a little micro quad I designed. The hardware I used for this build is the kit from http://shop.hovership.com/3dfly-micro-quad-kit/ ($110). Great little kit but I wanted a frame that could hold the all in one FPV camera VA1100, the MicroFrX FrSky compatible receiver, and Beef's Brushed Board without having to stack or use a bunch of hot glue. When printed in ABS, with 60% infill, its very flexible and only weighs 10 grams. Unfortunately a bit heavier when printed with PLA at the same infill, around 13 grams. It flys great with the Cleanflight, Luxfloat, and the PIDs you can find in one of the photos. This is a work in progress, suggestions and comments welcome.

I designed this Spool holder for my Cobblebot Little Monster 3D Printer. It uses a 1/2"x12" threaded rod, four nuts and four washers in addition to using four of the M3 x 10 and M3 T nuts. It mounts to the 8020 extrusion. You need print two of the clamp parts. Place one of the nuts and washers on the threaded rod, then one of the clamp parts, the filament spool, then the other clamp part with the washer and then nut. You can adjust it to the tension you desire so the spool will easily turn on the clamp parts.

Instructions Body: The body has a support on the bottom to become a clean print. The support has to be removed after printing. Infill: 15% Track: You'll need 64 tracks. Infill: 15% Pin: There are two different pins. The normal one is 3.7mm. If the chain is to tight, you should print the small one with 3.0mm and add 3-4 of those pins. After printing the pins, you have to remove the small support on each side. Infill: 15%-20% Small cog: You need 8 small cogs. Infill: 15% Main cog: You need 4 main cogs. Infill: For the first 10mm you can print it with 15%. For the rest you should use at least 90%. Rubbertrack: Use Flexifil or Ninjaflex for the rubber track and glue it to the track. The rubber tracks are not necessary but you will love it. Infill: 30%-50% Track2: If you don't want to print the rubber track or don't have Ninjaflex, you can print track2 instead of track + rubber track. Infill: 15% Front + back: Print this with brim if it doesn't stick to the surface and use support structure. Infill: 15% FPV-Cam holder: Print it with support structure and glue the small part on the back side. This is for the servo to move the cam up and down. Infill: 15% Camera and LED mount: You need these two parts if you want do use a fpv-camera. Infill: 15% Tow-bar: Infill: 15% Tow-bar plug: If you don't want to use the tow-bar you need this twice. Infill: 15% LED-mount: Infill: 15% Top: The top is designed to use a 40mm fan for cooling the vtx and to plug in the fpv-antenna from banggood. Infill: 15% Track-body-connector: You can glue the track frame together and glue it to the body but if you do that, you can't replace parts if broken. Use this to mount the track frame to the body. They are marked for front and back. Infill: 15% Track outer cover: Print this part twice. Infill: 15% Outer track frame: Print this part twice. Infill: 15% Inner track frame right/left. Infill: 15% Parts to print 1x body (for 2S or 3S)

The Brain for the FPV-Rover OSD PCB with sensors and usefull stuff for the FPV Rover The Rover-Brain is complete PDB with integratetd OSD, BEC, Current Sensor, Voltage Sensor, RSSI Filter, LC Filter, and 3 Step Switch. It´s to keep the FPV-Rover Clean of a wire mess and to have all necessary information of your onboard system in your Video-Downlink. http://fpv-treff.de/viewtopic.php?f=30&t=7625 https://github.com/Shortcircuitboards/Brain Upgrades The first upgrade for the FPV-Rover is ready.

Notes: Hope you can make use of this holder! Check out my other designs on my page and leave a comment if you used it.

The new FormLabs Form1 at the university has the serial number of "Good Wren"... so I needed a wren. Scintilla's Bird (for putting on things) became a great start. Dropped him into Meshmixer to move his beak up and make it a little smaller, move his tail up at an angle, flatten his back and head, and plump up his neck and we now have a fairly good approximation of a wren. To put on something.

The wren is sized at 36mm in the Y-axis but could be scaled as needed. It is printed on the Form1 on the Clear-0.5mm material setting and printed with support. The legs are very small and spindly at this size.

This is the part of the microwave oven door that fits into a recess and closes a switch when the door is closed.  If this part breaks off, the microwave won't operate.  Print a replacement so you don't have to wait a week for a new part!
This was the first thing I ever designed and printed.
Update - after several months of use the part showed some bending, probably due to a combination of exposure to steam escaping from the oven and the force of the spring tensioner.  I printed a second one with 100% infill and this time I installed it in the lower door position; hopefully this one will hold up better.  Probably ABS would also be a good idea (but I didn't have any white ABS so I stayed with PLA for now).

Done in Blender 2.76 by manually drawing the shape based on a bitmap and using extrude and solidify-modifier plus mesh-cleanup steps. Sliced in XYZware giving double-walls without holes. The ZIP file contains the STL file, but also the resulting 3w file and the original Blender file for modification. Blender Details
  • Start with scene, delete default object (in Edit mode)
  • Add "shape" bitmap in Z-projection (optional)
  • Create vertex loop (CTRL clicking), closed
  • Scale such, that 10 Blender units represent 10mm
  • clean-up loop (add/remove vertices), smooth etc.
  • Duplicate object (in Object mode) to have one for "upper" and one for "lower" part.
  • Extrude (in Edit mode) lower part 3 units downwards
  • Ensure face-normals point outward (Recompute normals if needed)
  • In Object mode, apply "Solidify modifier", no offset, thickness 0.5
  • Extrude (in Edit mode) upper part 10 units upwards
  • Ensure face-normals point outward (Recompute normals if needed)
  • In Object mode, apply "Solidify modifier", no offset, thickness 0.15
  • In Object mode, select both parts, then File/Export as STL

3 1/2 years ago a piece of our toilet seat broke. My wife still thinks Thing 26085 (yellow part in photos) is the best 3D print I have done. Last week, another part of the hinge broke and the other side of the hinge failed days later. So it was time to warm up the printer!

Printer:

Custom MakerSlide build

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Infill:

25%

Notes: This is an easy print. I printed in ABS. The only bridging is for the hinge and that is a gradual change. You do want good bed adhesion to keep the pieces flat for good fit. Since this is an easy print, I output both parts in one .stl file.

OpenScad Four years ago I used SketchUp for my 3D designs. This was ok for getting started, but it was a real pain to modify existing designs. About a year ago, I started using OpenScad and I haven't looked back. For this design, I used dimensions from the previous part and some simple measurements. My first iteration had the hinge point back too far and I had some clearance issues. A quick change and everything fit fine.

This thing is functional and I don't plan on making any improvements other than item 0 until there is another failure. This is the second of three hinge pieces to fail. When/If the third piece fails, I may improve the design. 0) Let wife pick color and reprint.
1) Slight clearance problem with top lid and the hinge.
2) Redesign top lid design.
3) Use polyhedron instead of cube for main base. Narrow the back for faster print and less material.
4) Have an entire set of hinge pieces. (Three different parts plus mirror pieces.)

description.text: If you own one of these power supplies you may want to protect others from electrical shock from the exposed power connections.

I designed this more as an experiment in precision reproduction of an existing part.
My showers were all leaking, and being installed in the mid-90's they all use the Moen 1225 cartridge, which is easily replaced and/or repaired.  Each kit comes with a tool that goes over the end and allows you to use a 1/2 inch wrench to break the cartridge loose.  Without this tool, it is said you can break your vice grips before actually pulling the thing out, the cartridge gets so set in there.
So if every kit comes with one of the tools, what is the point?  Well, like I said, it was an exercise in precision reproduction.  In reality though, as I looked at the system, it is very possible that in a number of cases just replacing the O-rings would bring the unit back to near new condition, and that would be impossible without the tool.  Thus this allows you to take a $20 repair, and make it sub $5 depending on what you pay for the O-rings.
I printed mine on a Mod-T printer.  Because of my goal I did .1mm layer height, and 100% infill.  I also have the model inverted with the wrench part on the base plate.  I don't know if that was really the best orientation, and that is why I have STL files both ways.  It certainly is slower!
Let me know if it works for you!

Printer:

NewMatter Mod-T

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.1

Infill:

100%

Notes: You can probably get away with thicker layers, but I would still do 100% infill, as you really don't want it breaking in there. You would then be in a world of hurt!

No real post printing other than removing supports and a little cleanup of the normal threads hanging around with a hobby knife.
Just in case the question comes up, the black one is the one I printed, the white is the original that came with the kit.  Not that it isn't obvious, but I'm just being thorough.
I used 123Design and a set of Harbor Freight digital calipers.  I included the 123Design file in the downloads for viewing and remixing.

title: "Original" Prusa i3 Y Axis End Stop

description.text:
This is a Y Axis End Stop for the "Original" Prusa i3 that comes from Prusa Research.  The kit has you zip tie the switch to the the 8mm round bar and this replaces the zip tie with something more robust.  Note that this version of the i3 has a 8mm top bar and a threaded 10mm bottom bar.  Also, the switch is 20x10x6 mm.  If you have a different switch or bar setup you can modify the included Open Scad file.
The part is held together with 3mm machine screws and nuts.  Note that the part is split down the Z axis such that you can install it without having to unplug and reroute the end stop wiring.

This is a thing I wanted to make for along time for my reef tank. The stock blade that comes with the Kent Algae scrapper works OK for what it is designed for but I needed more bite and was not happy with super gluing single edged razors to the insert. In the pictures the yellow one is the original that comes with the scrapper and I made it so you can insert 2 single edged razor blades into the slot. There may be some trimming needed after the print and you want the blades secure so a little misc plastic won't hurt. You could always add super glue to it but not needed. Also the hold in clip may not fit past the inner hole so just knock some of the point off until it fits snug. As a word of caution. Use this thing at your own risk. Serious injury can result if not careful inserting the razor blades. Watch out for fish and other mammals in your tanks when you use this. Also PLEASE keep out of reach of ALL children as we don't want them to get cut.
It is recommended that you insert the plastic into the Kent holder before you slide the razor blades in. If you need to remove the blades, use needle nose pliers to help pull them out for safety

author: ouchered

description.text:
This is an adapter that allows you to put D-mount (8mm film) cine lenses on a Micro 4/3rds camera. It will only work with moderately sized D-mount lenses, since the lens effectively sits inside the camera, there is extremely limited space available.   
I haven't printed this on an FDM machine, it has only been SLS'd by Shapeways, so printing this thing without support may be a challenge.  
The source files are included.  If anyone is looking for an accurate model of a Micro 4/3rds mount, this is also a good starting point.

comments.text: Do you have issues with overhang on the camera side of the lens adapter?
comments.author: Joe_Murphy

comments.text: I've only SLS'd this part, so I can't say for sure - however - my NEX E-mount adapter uses a similar amount of overhang for the bayonet mounts and I've printed it plenty of times on an Ultimaker without issue.

description.text:
This is just a quick coin tray that I made.  I started with a minimal one, but it didn't print well, I then moved on to a printable straight tray designed for one roll of coins.  Then I created this offset one.  Each of the three designs are in the scad, and each one corresponds to one roll of coins.
The STL files are for 2â‚¬, 1â‚¬, 0.50â‚¬, 0.20â‚¬ and 0.10â‚¬ coins respectively.  They are also adjusted to the tolerances of my Thingomatic Mk6.  The scad has a parametric cointray() module, that can easily be adjusted to any size coin, as well as any number of coins per counting offset, or to a different printing tolerance.
The counting tray is easy to load and unload, and should be useful to anyone who needs to count small amounts of change.
I had originally planned on printing them all on one tray, but that is larger than will fit in my printing bed.

You can try directly printing the STL files.
For for non-Euro based currency you can open up the scad and add your own coin measurements and generate STLs accordingly.

comments.text: That is great.  I have been trying to think of something I could do to count coins and this far exceeds anything I could have come up with. It is simple, printable, and so inventive. This is rocking, because I can make these and give them to friends. They then can instantly understand what a 3-D printer can do.
comments.author: jwnavagus

Using the star pattern from my Islamic Design Clothes Hanger (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1239548) I made a square screen, or mini jali* with the idea that multiple units could be fitted together to make one large screen. I have always loved the stone screens "jali" as I have written about on my blog: http://museumofperipheralart.blogspot.com/2014/08/the-second-millennium-stone-age.html I had a few problems printing this - not because of the design. A couple edges curled up and in the final passes the printer wigged out and started printing like a spider on acid. I had to cut off one corner (lower right in window shot) and cut out all the wayward filament, which took about half an hour. I am still happy with it. The file is final and the design is solid. *A jali or jaali, (Hindi:जाली jālī, meaning "net") is the term for a perforated stone or latticed screen, usually with an ornamental pattern constructed through the use of calligraphy and geometry. This form of architectural decoration is found in Indian architecture, Indo-Islamic Architecture and Islamic Architecture.

description.text: This is a PSU end cap for the MeanWell SE-350-xxx series of power supplies. It will also fit most clones including the 400W clones. (Indeed, a 400W, 24V clone is actually pictured here, but I've test fitted it on genuine MeanWell SE-350-24 units.) This design is derived from dc42's Thing 441081. See the Instructions Section of Thing 441081 for part numbers for the Neutrik 20A inlet and IEC power inlet. The OpenSCAD source file is also included and the critical dimensions are parametrized for convenience. And yes, there's two screw holes on one side and only one on the other side. That's not a mistake: that is as per the specs from MeanWell and verified by visual inspection of actual units.

Wow!
These things are cool.
Using the customizer, you can create a gear(s) that can have any size, and all dimensions of the gear and its teeth are customizable. Customizing in OpenSCAD is faster, and you can use my built in animation setup. Please ignore the "animate" variable when using Customizer. To animate this model, set your frame rate, and set the steps to 360. Then, change "animate" from 0 to 1. you can set it back to 0 to re-center the gears so they are 90 / 45 degrees offset instead of an arbitrary angle. Note:
When printing NON-double gears, be sure to mirror one of them. Otherwise, they will not mesh. When printing doubled gears, they will always mesh one way or another.

Strong protection (safety closure) cap for naked 18650 Li-ion batteries. High protection factor, reusable, easy to print, less material needs. Description:
This battery type (Li-Ion 18650) is probably the most commonly installed in laptop battery packs. If a laptop battery is defective, then all the cells are never useless. So it actually makes sense to carefully disassemble a notebook battery in all its components. Only for experienced users!
You can save money and resources if you do not always consider a new purchase.
Compliance with all safety-related regulations concerning the Li-Ion battery technology is mandatory. You should remember that a cell composite must always be equipped with protection electronics. Individual battery cells must be equipped again with a protective sheath. Then, these cells can be used easily in many compatible devices. A LED flashlight for 18650 Li-ion cells, for example, could be operated for many years reliably with a selected cell!

title: AG Thumbstick extender for PS4
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
We are serious gamers that need better accuracy and faster response! My personal biggest problem with the stock caps are:
  • your thumbs slip on the large surface (so you lose precision).
  • the sticks are too short.
    • Designed, tested and played to improve your FPS aim and accuracy. These caps are 6mm taller and has a textured pad so your thumbs don't slip. Let's face it, the stock PS4 thumbsticks were designed for the needs of an average of all age groups. Kids play it and adults play it... These are designed by a gamer FOR gamers.
For Xbox One go here : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1293627

FREE VERSION for my design is ALWAYS available here...
But if you want to contribute back to the design, you can visit Pinshape
https://pinshape.com/items/16014-3d-printed-ag-thumbstick-extender-for-ps4

Thanks for the positive response guys and your suggestions! Designed and uploaded 3 new thumbstick designs. Type A
Type B
Type C Mix and match the different types to find the perfect combo for your gaming style. My personal new fave combo is
LEFT thumb: Type C
RIGHT thumb: Original

title: SG-90 Servo auto bed level more precise system with switch

description.text:
As you know SG-90 Servos cheap and not so precise.
This design has one big circle.
Any where on green zone, that means arm is bed position
Any where on red piece means arm in park position.
The space between low and high around 5mm and tolerance is very high that means,
any value lower than 90° 0mm Park
any value higher than 90° 5mm on Bed (I use 0 and 150)

I needed to mount the Sense scanners to be able to use them better. Mounting 2 scanners on top of each other and taking the scan at the same time allows for being closer to the object which improves resolution. I've used a lot of saved things from the past, but the oval rails are from Ikea rack system, the rack was a CD rack that can be duplicated with a metal base and some "L" bars. If anybody needs modifications please contact me. It's an ongoing project I am presently adding a clip for a laser light to be able to center things better and also I need more lighting, so adapters for some kind of lighting are also in the making. The turntable is another thing on it's own but now I can scan pretty much anything that has a circumference of 4 feet and a height of 61/2 feet with a lot more resolution.

I recommend basically biopolymers, which are suitable for almost any reconstruction.

The original housing of my ODD was covered with a rubber coating. This rubber coating started to become sticky, and that after a very few months. Trashing I did not want this old ODD, so I picked it up, but no longer used it. For almost two years I have a 3D printer. Incidentally, I've learned even to construct things, and therefore there is for this old "SATA ODD" a new usage opportunity. Yes indeed almost 2016, and sometimes I burn a few CDs or DVDs. The work of writing data makes the LiteOn eSAU208 quite well and that's why I liked to make a new case for it. That's why I made this work available online: Maybe the casing fits to similar ODDs from other manufacturers. Of course, this will only work with max 13mm thick SATA ODDs. And its related USB to SATA bridge must have an almost identical basic shape. Good luck :-)
